captions.text:
KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: When you think
of land mines, countries

like Afghanistan, Sudan, Iraq,
and other conflict areas

around the world might
come to mind.

But Colombia is one of the most
affected countries in the
world, too.

Because for the last 50 years,
there's been a roiling

conflict between leftist Marxist
guerrillas and the
Colombian government.

And even though there are peace
talks happening right

now in Havana, the legacy of
decades of war are literally
sewn into the soil.

So we came to Colombia to find
out how this nation is dealing

with this ongoing, violent,
and brutal problem.

Since 1990, there have been over
10,000 land mine victims

in Colombia, the second most
in the world behind
Afghanistan.

Many victims are poor farmers
and ranchers who live in

regions controlled by the
guerrilla or other

narcotrafficking groups that
operate in the country.

But the Revolutionary Armed
Forces of Colombia, or FARC,

has been the government's
main enemy.

And even after over $5 billion
in US military aid, around

7,000 FARC soldiers are holding
off over 300,000

Colombian troops by surrounding
themselves with
land mines--
[EXPLOSION]

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: --their
strongest line of defense.

FARC has been around
for five decades.

And what began as a Marxist
people's army fighting against

capitalist imperialism has
devolved into a guerrilla

force that threatens the very
people it originally sought to

protect, because of the
thousands of land mines

they've buried in
civilian areas.

JORGE HUMBERTO JEREZ:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]
[EXPLOSION]

JORGE HUMBERTO JEREZ:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: Over the last
six months, FARC leaders

have been negotiating peace with
Columbia's government.

But even as they talk about
ending hostilities, there's no
ceasefire in place.

These negotiations could yield
a transformative moment in
Colombian history.

The government is even trying
to rebrand the country as a

vacation destination, not just
a hotbed of violence.

But the scars of 50 years of war
and 50 years of land mines
can't be so easily erased.

Victims of the conflict, who
have lived with war for most

if not all of their lives,
have little faith
in the peace process.

We're headed to Florencia,
which is in the southern
region of Caqueta.

Caqueta is a red zone, an active
combat area, that since

the late '90s has not only been
a stronghold of FARC but

has also been infiltrated by
right-wing paramilitary
groups, too.

So we're going to meet civilians
who have been caught

between the crossfire and have
been victims of land mines.
[MUSIC PLAYS]

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: Land mines
can be found all over

Colombia, especially in the
country's three mountain

ranges and dense jungle,
where the guerrilla
like to hide out.

Many of these areas can only
be accessed from a single

point of entry, so all it takes
is one set of land mines

to protect hundreds of acres
of territory and
foil any Army advances.

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: Ignacio Gomez
is an investigative

journalist who's been reporting
on the conflict for
over 20 years.

He's been targeted for
assassination five times,

including a personal
threat from cocaine
kingpin Pablo Escobar.

And even he thought it
was crazy that we
were heading to Florencia.

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU:
It sounds scary.

You're making me scared
to go there.

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: Caqueta is
one of Columbia's most

dangerous regions because coke
production has shot up there

by 80% over the last
few years.
It's basically FARC land.

And what's more, drug cartels
and their militias control
much of the region as well.

ANA DARNELLY
CUELLAR:[SPEAKING SPANISH]

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: In Columbia's
remote areas, it

takes hours to get proper
medical care for major trauma.

And the risk of infection for
land mine wounds is high,

especially because many of these
land mines are homemade

bombs, filled with things like
feces and battery acid.

So if you're lucky enough to
survive a mine blast, you'll

likely suffer lasting effects
of the injury.

JAMIE SANCHEZ:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

JAMIE'S MOTHER:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

JAMIE SANCHEZ:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

JAMIE'S MOTHER:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

JAMIE SANCHEZ:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

JAMIE'S MOTHER:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: Yeah,
she's very brave.
How does she feel now?

JAMIE SANCHEZ:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

JAMIE'S MOTHER:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]
[MUSIC PLAYS]

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: Yesterday
we met a few land
mine victims in Florencia.

And one thing they all shared
in common was that they were
displaced by the violence.

After they stepped on land
mines, they moved out of the

countryside to the relative
safety of the city.

But today we're going to head
into the guerrilla-controlled

countryside of Caqueta to meet
a few land mine victims who

are still living in an
active combat area.

Columbia counts 3.7 million
internally displaced people

and 380,000 refugees that have
fled the country entirely,

giving it the dubious honor of
having the highest number of

displaced people in the world,
beating out countries like
Afghanistan and Syria.

Entering FARC-controlled areas
is risky, especially for
journalists.

Our driver charged us double
and would only spend a few
hours out there.

He refused to stop the car for
more than a few minutes.

We met up with Francisney, who
lost his leg on the side of
the road years ago.

FRANCISNEY CHAUX:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: So can
you show your leg, the
prosthetic you have?

FRANCISNEY CHAUX:
[SPEAKING SPANISH]

KRISHNA ANDAVOLU: A week later,
we learned that a

soldier lost his leg by stepping
on a land mine that

was just feet from
where we were.

comments.text:
El mundo debe saber que el gobierno Colombiano está en la capacidad de 
acabar militarmente a la guerrilla. Lo que ocurre es que no hay voluntad. 
Un ejemplo, un día estuve en uno de los combates aéreos de la fuerza aérea 
Colombiana, cuando llegué a Bogotá a donde vivía, me puse a ver noticias, 
la noticia era que 10 policías por allá en el Cauca llevaba combatiendo 
como a 100 guerrilleros durante 9 horas. Dicha noticia me entristeció mucho 
porque un par de horas antes yo veía 20 helicópteros de guerra 
estacionados. No hay voluntad. Además los políticos, los gobiernos más 
bien, no quieren que la guerrilla se acabe para recibir dinero de USA, de 
algo llamado el plan Colombia.﻿
comments.author: carlos ospina

comments.text:
De acuerdo. Pero realmente este tipo de grupos se alimentan es de la 
desigualdad. No necesariamente porque así lo quiso la gente. Muchas veces 
estan obligados a hacerlo. Me parece importante que hablaste de la relación 
con el crimen, y puede ser que tengas razón, pero la guerrilla va más alla 
de eso, ellos ya se estructuran como un ejercito irregular y no se les 
puede ver como simples criminales, quieranlo o no muchos políticos 
colombianos. Un simple criminal no controla zonas enteras de un país. 
Saludos!
comments.author: Nicolas Cardona

comments.text:
+Nicolas Cardona
De los pocos cursos que he tomado sobre criminologia el crimen organizado o 
crimen en general no se da solo por factores de desigualdad social, eso 
puede ser uno de los factores, sin embargo hay mucha gente pobre que 
trabaja y sobrevive como puede sin robar, matar, sobornar, o entrar a 
formar parte de la guerrilla.. Hay factores culturales que a veces influyen 
mas que la pobreza o desigualdad social. Y despues hay idiotas que se meten 
porque que se yo les resulta romantico o estan cansados de tomas cafe en 
starbucks como la guerrillera holandesa Tanja Nijmeijer, que encima sale 
diciendo "Nosotros estamos en guerra" como si ella hubiera nacido dentro de 
padres guerrilleros o algo por el estilo.

comments.text:
En ningun momento estoy justificando el terrorismo. Decime hermano cuando 
he justificado la existencia de la guerrilla con eso. Una cosa es 
justificar y otra cosa es ver ciertas razones de fondo que dan CONTINUIDAD. 
¿No te parece lógico que las partes mas pobres y abandonadas del pais sean 
las que mas tienen cultivos ilicitos y precensia de guerrillas? ¿Aca no 
estan diciendo que muchas veces el gobierno continua la guerra por negocio? 
¿De donde saca la guerrilla todos los jovenes y niños que los obligan a 
portar un fusil o que escogen por dinero facil o una salida en su vida? ¿No 
confiaria las personas mas el ejercito si aparte de llevarles hombres que 
los protegan se les llevase carreteras, escuelas y hospitales? Es que 
hermano una cosa es el terrorismo y el negocio de la droga, y otra cosa es 
la realidad del pais. Es mas, no hablemos de guerrilla ni terrorismo, 
hablemos de las pandillas en las ciudades: ¿Donde se originan?

What you say has some truth actually. But not in the context you believe. 
The FARC has been around longer than the current form of US-Colombian 
relations. The Colombian government has failed to kill off the FARC because 
the money and equipment they get from the Plan Colombia to fight drug 
trafficking keeps pouring in. Kill them all off or end the conflict and 
that money is gone. Of course a good portion of those funds ends up lining 
politicians' pockets so its not about bowing down to the gringo masters, 
but pretending to follow their example and take a nice fat check at the end 
of the day.

comments.text:
The main threat to peace in Colombia is corruption and inequality, mainly 
encouraged by the Colombian goverments corrupt relationship with the USA. 
Did you know that the USA exports fruit to Colombia and does not have to 
pay import taxes? Surprising really since Colombia could grow any fruit in 
any quantity that it needs. It's bad enough that they import any fruit at 
all, let alone not require the exporter (US fucking A) to pay taxes. As you 
can imagine, this has been the source of civil unrest in recent months as 
the agricultural workers here are in poverty because they can't compete 
with cheap US imports.﻿

comments.author: jo Gomez

comments.text:
I went to the jungles of Putumayo and the forests of Saravena in Arauca. 
I've spoken with Colombian soldiers as they sorted cocaine and smoked 
marijuana. And I also spoke with FARC rebels. Of course, I wasn't kidnapped 
by either side, contrary to the speculation that the FARC 'are 
indiscriminate mass murderers who love and thrive on killing Westerners'. 
Let me tell you; although Colombia needs peace, this video is so one-sided 
that it should be viewed with serious suspicion. It's sensationalist, and 
pretends to want to help Colombia but actually hurts the Colombian people 
by selecting the facts and ignoring others. Vice should be ashamed of 
themselves. ﻿

comments.text:
+truefalse I see what you are saying but my argument is Unionists are a 
minority on the whole Island of Ireland and in the 1920's the vast majority 
of the population of Ireland voted for home rule.  For instance if people 
in East Germany tomorrow said they want their own state in East Germany 
because they are (loyal) to Communism why should they get that state if the 
vast* majority of Germans do not want that. The mandate in the North of 
Ireland is that the majority rule IE: the majority of people in the 
artificial North Eastern counties want to remain part of the UK  but the 
Majority* of Irish men and women voted for home rule. The Northern Irish 
state was created after the Home rule bill therefore making it illegitimate 
 the idea of creating a country within a very small island because a small 
minority of the whole country want to remain with a different country is 
absurd.
comments.author: Veritas et fortitudo

comments.text:
+Veritas et Fortitudo You do not understand the situation whatsoever. 
Northern Ireland was created in 1916 because NI was the only region on the 
island of Ireland that wanted to be part of the UK, the majority of the 
population in NI are pro-British of Scottish & English descent. If you've 
ever been to NI you will see streets covered in Union Jacks. Northern 
Ireland is the most pro-British part of the UK. A lot of people in NI would 
be offended if you called them Irish. I do agree NI is an artificial state 
but I'm just explaining how it is. 
http://www.apersonalguide.co.uk/northern_ireland/images/046_Belfast_Shankill_Road.jpg 
photo from Belfast, Northern Ireland
comments.author: truefalse

comments.text:
+truefalse Actually the Irish people in the island of Ireland 1920's voted 
in favor of a United Ireland the Unionists are a minority anyone can carve 
up a country with artificial borders the fact is the majority of Irish 
people voted for independence I can provide you links to the right 
honorable George Galloway discussing the phantom Northern Ireland state if 
you wish? By your logic the Cornish people in Cornwall have a right to 
break away from the UK and England because they are a minority.
comments.author: Veritas et fortitudo

comments.text:
+Veritas et Fortitudo The IRA fought for a United Ireland, they did not 
achieve a United Ireland therefore they didn't win. A lot of people in 
Northern Ireland are of Scottish/English descent and identify themselves as 
British and not Irish. Those British people in Northern Ireland do not want 
to be part of a United Ireland, hence why there is a lot of anti-IRA 
paramilitaries in Northern Ireland like the UVF, UFF, RHC, UDA, UYM, UR, 
LVF, OV. It's not a simple case of IRA vs. Brits.
comments.author: truefalse

comments.text:
The thing with VICE is that they always TEND to show the bad things of 
situations, but it is understandable because that is what people are 
looking for, impacting news. I don't like the focus too much on the bad 
side, but I like the fact that this is being shown to people around the 
globe from an international perspective. It is also very good, the fact 
that they are using PROVEN statistics, I am Colombian, and like it or not, 
this is our story, something we have to fix for future generations...Thx 
VICE for showing interest in the conflict.﻿
